table.name: mem
table.column: In other words, "upload" (or possibly "download", depending on context).

table.name: mem
table.column: übertreiben (zu oft oder zu nachdrücklich tun)

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: A patron at a {Qe':n} may {lajQo':v:nolink} a dish if the {jabwI':n} has {qawHa':v}.[1, p.102]

table.name: mem
table.column: Mary had a little "lamb", and its fleece was not white as snow.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {nuqDaq Dochvam vIlan?:sen} ▶ {HurDaq tu'HomI'raHvetlh yIlan!:sen:nolink} "Get that piece of junk out of here!"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: Something that is "long" is usually thin.

table.name: mem
table.column: flattern (wie Flügel eines Vogels, nicht wie Fahne)

This verb describes movement like that of a bird's wings, and not like that of a flag (for which see {joq:v}). In flight, a bird's wings {laq:v:nolink}, and the bird is said to {laqmoH@@laq:v, -moH:v} its wings.
The example comes from the KLI web site and not from the HolQeD article itself.

table.name: mem
table.column: ink up, put paint on a brush

This is used both for the act of transferring ink from a {rItlh 'echlet:n} to a {toqwIn:n}, and the act of putting paint on a {rItlh naQ:n}.
A slang term for this action is {pID:v:2}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the name of a {veng:n} located in {'amerI'qa' SepjIjQa':n} on {tera':n}.
The Las Vegas Hilton hotel was the site of a themed attraction called Star Trek The Experience. The name of the city appeared in Klingon in the invitation to the grand opening.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This is defined only as "shrine" in {KGT:src}. The definition "monument, memorial (building)" was added at the {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2016:src}.
In English slang, a "lat"rine is sometimes called a "shrine".

table.name: mem
table.column: The suffix for the plural of this word depends on whether it is used to refer to beings capable of language (see {-pu':n:suff}), body parts (see {-Du':n:suff}), or things which are neither (see {-mey:n:suff}).
▶ {reH latlh qabDaq qul tuj law' Hoch tuj puS.:sen}[2] ▶ {yIntaH qIrq 'e' vIneH. DaSwIj bIngDaq latlhpu' vItap.:sen:nolink} "Kirk I want alive. The rest I will grind beneath my boot."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: Pour the cold bloodwine into another glass!
Gieße den kalten Blutwein in ein anderes Glas!
This idiomatic expression means "I don't believe you, maybe someone else will", or "That is irrelevant to me, maybe someone else will care."

table.name: mem
table.column: People often just use a shrub when they can't find a "lav"atory.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a traditional (in the sense of having been used a long time ago but no longer in use today) unit of angle. There are 243 {lawmey:n:nolink} in a {gho:n}. (Note that 243 is 3 to the 5th power.)

table.name: mem
table.column: This is a modern unit of angle adopted from other civilizations in the galaxy. It is also referred to as a {law chu':n:nolink} (although that term is used less and less). There are 360 {lawrI'mey:n:nolink} in a {gho:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The word {law':v:nolink} is used in comparative constructions. See {... X law' ... X puS:sen}.

table.name: mem
table.column:
This construction is used to form comparatives and superlatives. The two things being compared go into the two slots. To form the superlative, {Hoch:n} is used in the second slot.[1]
Other antonym pairs may be substituted in place of {law':v} and {puS:v:1} as a form of word play.[2]
To say that something is not more {X:sen:nolink} than something else, {law'be':v:nolink} and {puSbe':v:nolink} are used instead of {law':v:nolink} and {puS:v:nolink}. To say that something is as {X:sen:nolink} as something else, {law':v:nolink} is used with {law':v:nolink} (if the quality or its possession is considered positive), or {puS:v:nolink} is used with {puS:v:nolink} (if the quality or its possession is considered negative), or {law':v:nolink} is used with {rap:v} or {nIb:v} (the latter of which implies the two things being compared are exactly the same in some way). It is also possible to use {puS:v:nolink} with {rap:v} or {nIb:v}, but that carries a connotation of disparagement. To say that something is not as {X:sen:nolink} as something else, {pIm:v} is used in place of the second verb in the pair.[3]
To say that two things have the same amount of some quality, it's also possible to use {rap:v} or {nIb:v} without a {law':v:nolink}/{puS:v:nolink} construction. (See those verbs for details.)
The above constructions are typically used only to compare similar things. To form similes, which compare things which are unlike, use {rur:v} instead. When the above constructions are used to compare unlike things, they generally reference well-known similes.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is some sort of technical term. It would be odd to say {lay vItlhuH:sen@@lay:n:2, vI-:v, tlhuH:v:1} for "I breathe air", but it would be understood.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: A planet in the Ferengi Alliance.

table.name: mem
table.column: The {la'quv:n:nolink} is head of the Klingon High Council, and the highest ranked {yaS:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a Klingon creature that resembles a Terran turtle, which might be called a {tera' la'SIv:n:nolink}.
Source is an e-mail from MO to loghaD.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an officer in charge of certain specialized units within the military.

table.name: mem
table.column: be perpendicular, be at a right angle
This is normally used with a plural subject.
▶ {leD rav tlhoy' je@@leD:v, rav:n:1, tlhoy':n, je:conj} "The floor and the wall are perpendicular (to each other)."[1]
▶ {leD rav tlhoy' je@@leD:v, rav:n:1, tlhoy':n, je:conj} "Der Boden und die Wand sind rechtwinklig (zu einander)."[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {pa'vo' pagh leghlu'.:sen:nolink} "The room has no view."
▶ {pa'vo' pagh leghlu'.:sen:nolink} "Das Zimmer hat keinen Ausblick."

table.name: mem
table.column: A sharp knife is nothing without a sharp eye.
Ein scharfes Messer ist wertlos ohne ein scharfes Auge

table.name: mem
table.column: For the removal of something from the exterior, consider {teq:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The inhabitants of Lenmak use an eight-day week ({Hogh:n}).

table.name: mem
table.column:
{leng:v:nolink} works like {jaH:v}.[2]
This word can be used to refer to traveling with or without a special purpose. If it is desired to indicate traveling on a mission, use {ve':v} instead.[3]

▶ {yuQ vIleng.:sen:nolink} or {yuQDaq vIleng.:sen:nolink} "I travel to the planet." ▶ {yuQvo' jIleng.:sen:nolink} "I roam away from the planet." ▶ {yuQDaq jIleng.:sen:nolink} "I roam around/about on the planet."

▶ {yuQ vIleng.:sen:nolink} oder {yuQDaq vIleng.:sen:nolink} "Ich reise zum Planeten" ▶ {yuQvo' jIleng.:sen:nolink} "Ich reise vom Planeten weg." ▶ {yuQDaq jIleng.:sen:nolink} "Ich reise auf dem Planeten."

table.name: mem
table.column: This may be applied to any meal, e.g. {leng megh:n:nolink} "voyage lunch" (see {megh:n}). See {KGT p.103:src} for a fuller explanation.

table.name: mem
table.column: "Voyage cancellation insurance" was an odd concept for Maltz, and not a term or phrase he had heard before, but he said that {leng chach mab:n:nolink} "voyage emergency contract" would be understood by Klingons to mean an agreement about who is responsible for what, if something goes wrong during a journey.

table.name: mem
table.column: This can also refer to a button, such as on an {'eQway':n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: "Purell" is a brand of hand sanitiser.

table.name: mem
table.column: Les Paul was an American guitarist.

table.name: mem
table.column:
For "be hard (be difficult)", see {Qatlh:v}.
This word can be used figuratively. There is an idiom, {let mInDu'Daj; Separmey rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The stairway leading to door of a ship is referred to by a more specific word, {choghvat:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: stairway leading to door of a ship
In some {meqro'vaq Sep:n} dialects, this refers to what is elsewhere called a {choghvat:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: The soft palate is known as the "vel"um.

table.name: mem
table.column: move bat'leth from vertical to horizontal orientation
das Bat'leth von der Senkrechte in die Waagerechte bewegen

table.name: mem
table.column: The word for nose is {ghIch:n} everywhere, but in some regions this word is used as an alternative.[1, p.28]
The regions where this word is used are not specified in {KGT:src}.[1, p.28]

table.name: mem
table.column: This can be used in the sense of "general" (as opposed to specific). For example, {nav HablI' le'be'} might refer to the general or shared fax machine at the front desk of an office, as opposd to a fax machine at someone's desk.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: A reference to a famous scene from Les Miserables.
▶ {DIvI' le'mISvo' bInargh.:sen:nolink} "Entkomme der Blockade der Föderation."[1]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: The prefix in the example sentence is incorrect, as it should be {bo-:v:pref}. Possibly it was mixed up with {lI-:v:pref}, which forced {lIb:v:nolink} to be created.
▶ {Qob lIb bam SoH chuDlI' je.@@Qob:n, lIb:v, bam:v, SoH:n, chuD:n, -lI':n, je:conj} "You and your people are in danger."
▶ {Qob lIb bam SoH chuDlI' je.@@Qob:n, lIb:v, bam:v, SoH:n, chuD:n, -lI':n, je:conj} "Du und deine Leute sind in Gefahr."

table.name: mem
table.column: This is also called {lIghonya':n:nolink}, typically by older speakers.[1, p.141-142]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is often pronounced as if it were {lIghongan:n:nolink}[1, p.141]

table.name: mem
table.column: This means to begin to sing a song (the singer is the subject and the song is the object).[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The idea is that the subject of the verb looks or behaves like something (or someone) else or represents something (or someone) else. Like {ghet:v}, it has no connotation of fraud or anything underhanded. The object is the thing being simulated or the person being impersonated. A {lIlwI':n@@lIl:v, -wI':v} is different from a {lIw:n} since the latter implies replacement, whereas a {lIlwI':n:nolink} doesn't replace anyone or anything.
▶ {'IDnar pIn'a' lIl:sen:nolink} "er/sie simuliert einen Zauberer (ohne Betrugsabsicht)"

table.name: mem
table.column: When {A:sen:nolink} and {B:sen:nolink} share {C:sen:nolink} with each other, the construction is {C lulIn A B je:sen:nolink} (or {C lIn A B je:sen:nolink} if {C:sen:nolink} is plural). In this case, the speaker is non-committal about whether {A:sen:nolink} or {B:sen:nolink} is the one who decided to do the sharing with the other.

table.name: mem
table.column: This idiomatic expression is not a euphemism, but is a little risque. It means that the subjects have a physical relationship of some sort.

table.name: mem
table.column: Edward Lear was the author of the poem "The Owl and the Pussycat".

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {jol SeHlaw lItHa'!} "Get off that transporter control panel!"[2]
▶ {jol SeHlaw lItHa'!} "Komm von der Transporterkonsole herunter!"[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a temporary substitute or stand-in. To denote a permanent replacement, use {qa'meH:n}.[2]

This is a substitute in "lieu" of something.
This was used to refer to "variables" (a memory location used for storing data in a computer program) in Klingon Blockly.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This could mean "download" or "upload", depending on the context.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to a state of matter.

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to hair on the upper lip.

table.name: mem
table.column: I am not a merry man.

table.name: mem
table.column: loDHom jIHDI' qIrq qun vIqImchoH. ghotvam Ho'lu'... 'ej muSlu'.
I've followed his history since I was a boy. A man to admire... and hate.
Als ich ein Kind war habe ich seine Geschichte verfolgt. Man bewundert ihn. Und man hasst ihn.
This line was cut from {Star Trek V:src}.

table.name: mem
table.column: A "brother-in-law" is {loDnI' loDnal:n@@loDnI':n, loDnal:n} or {be'nI' loDnal:n@@be'nI':n, loDnal:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: In Klingon, "deep space" is called {logh Hop:n}, literally, "far space".[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is appended to a number to form an adverbial meaning that many times. For example, {wa'logh:adv} "once, one time" from {wa':n:num} "one", {cha'logh:adv} "twice, two times" from {cha':n:num} "two", and so on.

table.name: mem
table.column: loghDaq Suvrupbogh SuvwI'pu' chaH Hoch SuvwI'pu''e'.
In space, all warriors are cold warriors.
Im Weltraum sind alle Krieger kalte Krieger.

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: This refers to a line in "Lady Madonna" by The Beatles: "Thursday night your stockings needed mending." (See {paSlogh:n}.)

table.name: mem
table.column: This refers to the central processing unit of a computer.

table.name: mem
table.column: alle sein, nicht mehr da sein

table.name: mem
table.column: No one eavesdrops at an open door.
Niemand lauscht an einer offenen Tür.

table.name: mem
table.column: {lojmItjaj:n:nolink} tends to be used on formal occasions, while both it and {ghInjaj:n:nolink} are used, seemingly indiscriminately, otherwise.
This refers to a line in "Being for the Benefit of Mr. Kite!" by The Beetles, which partly goes "on Saturday at Bishopsgate".

table.name: mem
table.column: be in a stance, be in a pose (people, animals, or martial arts)
in einer bestimmten Pose stehen (Personen, Tiere oder Kampfsport)

table.name: mem
table.column:
Note that there is a homophonous verb {lol:v:1} which can be applied to people or animals.
Some of the verb suffixes have a precise meaning when used with this verb, when it is applied to aircraft or spacecraft: {lolchu':v} "be in a correct attitude" {lolchu'taH:v} "maintain a correct attitude" {lolmoH:v} "maneuver (an aircraft) to be in an attitude" {loltaH:v} "maintain an attitude"

table.name: mem
table.column: a specific position in the martial arts form Mok'bara
bestimmte Stellung in der Kampfsportart Mok'bara

table.name: mem
table.column: It is unknown if this is used outside the context of aircraft attitude.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is unknown if this is used outside the context of aircraft attitude.

table.name: mem
table.column: maneuver (an aircraft) to be in an attitude
▶ {qughmeH Duj vIlolmoH.:sen:nolink} "I put the vessel in the attitude for cruise (or cruising)."

table.name: mem
table.column: This word is plural. Its singular form is unknown. It appears to consist of the elements {lol:v:2}, {SeH:v}, and {cha:n}, or homophones thereof.

table.name: mem
table.column: It is unknown if this is used outside the context of aircraft attitude.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {ja'chuq Dalopchu'. Qang Damoj.:sen:nolink} "Complete the Rite of Succession to become Chancellor."[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: This is an event to which the spirits of ancestors are invited.

table.name: mem
table.column: A warrior does not complain about physical discomfort.
Ein Krieger beschwert sich nicht über Unannehmlichkeiten.

table.name: mem
table.column: This word refers to one's mother's brother's child or one's father's sister's child (i.e., "cross-cousins").

table.name: mem
table.column: For a man, this word refers to a child of his sister. For a woman, this word refers to a child of her brother.

table.name: mem
table.column: A female {lor:n}, that is, a cousin who is one's mother's brother's daughter or one's father's sister's daughter, or a niece in the sense of a man's sister's daughter or a woman's brother's daughter.

table.name: mem
table.column: A male {lor:n}, that is, a cousin who is one's mother's brother's son or one's father's sister's son, or a nephew in the sense of a man's sister's son or a woman's brother's son.

table.name: mem
table.column: fourth tone of nonatonic musical scale
The tones of the Klingon musical scale (see {yutlhegh:n}) are: {yu:n}, {bIm:n}, {'egh:n}, {loS:n:2,nolink}, {vagh:n:2}, {jav:n:2}, {Soch:n:2}, {chorgh:n:2}, {yu:n:nolink}.

table.name: mem
table.column: Quadrotriticale is a four-lobed hybridization of wheat (genus Triticum) and rye (genus Secale).

table.name: mem
table.column: a bird that swoops into the water in order to catch food, but cannot swim
ein Vogel der zur Nahrungssuche ins Wasser taucht, aber nicht schwimmen kann

table.name: mem
table.column: A planet in the Cardassian Union.

table.name: mem
table.column: This preceeds the noun it modifies.
▶ {lo' law' choQ:n:nolink} "utility deck" (see {choQ:n} for the complete example) ▶ {lo' law' lojmIt:n} "utility hatch"

table.name: mem
table.column: This is not the verb {lo':v} with the suffix {-laH:v}.[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: See {chetvI':n:1} for an idiom related to worthlessness.

table.name: mem
table.column:
See {pum:v:2} for a literal fall.
{lu qeng:n:name,nolink} "The Fall of Kang" is a famous poem by G'trok.[1, p.107]

table.name: mem
mem
table.column: There is an idiom, {lugh; Sor rur}.

table.name: mem
table.column: cause (someone) to confess or reveal a secret

table.name: mem
table.column: Source is a letter from MO to Quvar, dated Nov. 15, 2010.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is defined as "fail" in {TKD:src}, and as "lose (not win)" in {KGT:src}. In {HQ 2.4:src} it is explained that these are the same word.[3]

table.name: mem
table.column: In ascending order of ferocity, the verbs used to describe military confrontations are: {Qor:v}, {tlhaS:v}, {vay:v}, {lul:v:nolink}, {Hargh:v}.

table.name: mem
table.column: This looks like "they ride it", but it's probably a coincidence.

table.name: mem
table.column: This is the Chinese word for "dragon" (龍). MO confirmed at {Saarbrücken qepHom'a' 2011:src} that this was deliberate.

table.name: mem
table.column: {HIj:v} is used for transporting goods, whereas it seems that {lup:v:nolink} is used for transporting people.

table.name: mem
table.column: The existence of this word is inferred from {lupDujHom:n}.

table.name: mem
table.column: My hovercraft is full of eels.

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {nuqDaq lupwI' mIr vItIj?} "Where is the train station?"[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The name is written as {luqara:n:nolink} once in the introduction, but is {luqara':n:nolink} (with a final {qaghwI':n}) consistently throughout the text.[1]

table.name: mem
table.column: The Klingon sentence on {SkyBox 13:src} seems to have dropped some words, since it is ungrammatical.

table.name: mem
table.column:
The Klingon compass has three points, rather than four: {chan:n} (east), {'ev:n} (northwest), and {tIng:n} (southwest).
The areas around an object are its {Dung:n} (area above), {bIng:n} (area below), {retlh:n} (area beside), {tlhop:n:1} (front), and {'em:n} (behind). Something in an object's {retlh:n:nolink} can be on its {poS:n} (left) or its {nIH:n} (right). The area between two objects are their {joj:n} (area between).
In standard Klingon, locative nouns follow pronouns, e.g., {jIH tlhop:n:nolink} "in front of me". But in the dialect of the Sakrej region ({Sa'Qej Sep:n}), locative nouns take pronominal possessive suffixes, e.g., {tlhopwIj:n:nolink} "my area in front".[2] However, the directional nouns are an exception to this rule, and take possessive suffixes in every known dialect, e.g., {chanwIj:n:nolink} "east of me, to my east". If the full pronoun is used with a directional noun, the pronoun is emphasized, e.g., {jIH chan:n:nolink} "east of ME, to MY east".[4]
The points in between the three cardinal directions are {tIng chan:n:nolink}, {'ev chan:n:nolink}, and either {tIng 'ev:n:nolink} or {'ev tIng:n:nolink}. {chan:n:nolink} always comes second in such a compound.[3]

▶ {veng chanDaq jIwam.:sen:nolink} "I hunt east of the city." ▶ {chan vengDaq jIwam.:sen:nolink} "I hunt in the city in the east." ▶ {veng chan yoSDaq jIwam.:sen:nolink} "I hunt in the city's east (the eastern part of the city)." ▶ {'evmajDaq jIwampu'.:sen:nolink} "I have hunted northwest of here." (Northwest is relative to the speaker's location.) ▶ {Daqvam 'ev jIwampu'.:sen:nolink} "I have hunted northwest of here." (Northwest is relative to a location indicated by the speaker, for example a point on a map.)

table.name: mem
table.column: Sister of B'Etor and Duras. She is portrayed by the actress {barbara' ma'rIch:n:name}.

▶ {DuraS tuq tlhIngan yejquv patlh luDub 'e' reH lunIDtaH DuraS be'nI'pu' lurSa' be'etor je. ngoQvam luchavmeH ghawran maghpu' be'nI'pu'. woQ luSuqmeH jIjpu' chaH romuluSngan'e' je.:sen:nolink} "The sisters of the House of Duras, Lursa and B'Etor, are constantly seeking a higher standing for the House of Duras within the Klingon High Council. To this end, the sisters have acted against Gowron, going as far as to work with Romulan factions in order to gain power."[2]

table.name: mem
table.column: ▶ {meb, lut tlhaQ DaSov'a'?} "Guest, do you know any funny stories?"[2]
